description: From Middle English flitten, flytten, from Old Norse flytja (“to move”), from Proto-Germanic *flutjaną, from Proto-Indo-European *plewd- (“to flow; run”). Cognate Icelandic flytja, Swedish flytta, Danish flytte, Norwegian flytte, Faroese flyta. Compare also Saterland Frisian flitskje (“to rush; run quickly”).

adjectives.description: flit (comparative more flit, superlative most flit)

entries.meaning: (physics) A particular, unexpected, short lived change of state.
examples: My computer just had a flit.

verbs.description: flit (third-person singular simple present flits, present participle flitting, simple past and past participle flitted)

entries.meaning: To move about rapidly and nimbly.
examples: A shadow flits before me, / Not thou, but like to thee;  […]

entries.meaning: To move quickly from one location to another.
examples: By their means it became a received opinion, that the souls of men departing this life, do flit out of one body into some other.

entries.meaning: (physics) To unpredictably change state for short periods of time.
examples: My blender flits because the power cord is damaged.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect) To move house (sometimes a sudden move to avoid debts).
examples: […]  we can't give any one house-room just now, for every Christmas Eve such a pack of Trolls come down upon us that we are forced to flit, and haven't so much as a house over our own heads, to say nothing of lending one to any one else.

entries.meaning: To move a tethered animal to a new, grazing location.
To be unstable; to be easily or often moved.
examples: the free soul to flitting air resign'd
